body_html:
I wrote two examples
tf_save.py and tf_restore.py.

In tf_save.py, collection is used to save the useful variables. And in tf_restore.py, it is used to restore the useful varibales, such as inputs, outputs, etc.

Conclusion is the apis are right, but you need to use something like collection to save the variables you need to restore, such as inputs and outputs. It took me quite a time to understand this. Hope this will help others.

Thanks!
body_text:
I wrote two examples
tf_save.py and tf_restore.py.
In tf_save.py, collection is used to save the useful variables. And in tf_restore.py, it is used to restore the useful varibales, such as inputs, outputs, etc.
Conclusion is the apis are right, but you need to use something like collection to save the variables you need to restore, such as inputs and outputs. It took me quite a time to understand this. Hope this will help others.
Thanks!
body:
I wrote two examples 
[tf_save.py](https://gist.github.com/benwu232/6b90d6571cc19c5ebb5294919d9f677d) and [tf_restore.py](https://gist.github.com/benwu232/73d95d930c5e1f1555acc91de2a27bf8). 

In tf_save.py, collection is used to save the useful variables. And in tf_restore.py, it is used to restore the useful varibales, such as inputs, outputs, etc.

Conclusion is the apis are right, but you need to use something like collection to save the variables you need to restore, such as inputs and outputs. It took me quite a time to understand this. Hope this will help others.

Thanks!
